thread.title: 'Very likely' that missing debris is that of MH370
thread.title_full: 'Very likely' that missing debris is that of MH370

title: 'Very likely' that missing debris is that of MH370
text:
Save 
The man heading the search operation for missing flight MH370 has said it is “very likely” that debris found on the island of Reunion is that of the lost plane. 
Martin Dolan, who is in charge of Australia’s search efforts, also insisted that the operation was continuing “in the right place”, in the southern part of the ocean. 
The wreckage is thought to have come from a wing part, and will be flown to France for analysis. 
There were 239 passengers and crew onboard the MH370 aircraft when it disappeared in March 2014 while travelling from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing. 
The debris washed up on the Reunion island in the Indian ocean on Wednesday, some 2,500 miles from the area where the MH370 is thought to have disappeared. 
Dolan, who heads the Australian Transport Safety Bureau, told the BBC that he was “increasingly confident that the wreckage… is associated with a 777 aircraft”. 
Aviation experts who have studied photos of the debris suggest that it resembles a flaperon – a moving part of the wing surface – from a Boeing 777. 
“There is no other recorded case of a flaperon being lost from a Boeing 777,” Mr Dolan said. 
“We are confident we have the quality of the search to cover that area and find the missing aircraft,” he added. 
Authorities believe the plane went down in the southern Indian Ocean, after using signals from the plane that were detected by satellite, 
After finding no physical evidence of the what had happened to the plane, the Malaysian authorities declared in January that all on board were presumed dead.
